tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires finding the value of alpha for which the system has a non-trivial solution, which involves setting the determinant of the coefficient matrix to zero and solving for alpha. This involves a few steps of calculation but doesn't require deep conceptual understanding.

answer_validation.reasoning: For a homogeneous system of linear equations \\textbf{A}\\textbf{x} = 0 to have a non-trivial solution, the coefficient matrix \\textbf{A} must be singular, i.e., det(\\textbf{A}) = 0. Setting up the 3x3 determinant and solving yields \\alpha = 3. This aligns with the retrieved knowledge stating that non-trivial solutions exist when the rank of the coefficient matrix is less than the number of unknowns (here, rank < 3).

step_by_step: Step 1: Recognize that a homogeneous system \\textbf{A}\\textbf{x} = 0 has non-trivial solutions if and only if the determinant of the coefficient matrix \\textbf{A} is zero (for a square system).
Step 2: Write the coefficient matrix \\textbf{A} from the given equations: \\textbf{A} = \\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -2 & \\alpha \\\\ 2 & 1 & -4 \\\\ 1 & -1 & 1 \\end{bmatrix}.

Step 3: Compute the determinant of \\textbf{A}: det(\\textbf{A}) = 1 \\cdot \\begin{vmatrix} 1 & -4 \\\\ -1 & 1 \\end{vmatrix} - (-2) \\cdot \\begin{vmatrix} 2 & -4 \\\\ 1 & 1 \\end{vmatrix} + \\alpha \\cdot \\begin{vmatrix} 2 & 1 \\\\ 1 & -1 \\end{vmatrix}.
Step 6: Set det(\\textbf{A}) = 0 for non-trivial solution: 9 - 3\\alpha = 0, solving gives \\alpha = 3.
formulas_used: $\\text{det}(\\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\\\ d & e & f \\\\ g & h & i \\end{bmatrix}) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)$
$\\text{det}(\\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\\\ c & d \\end{bmatrix}) = ad - bc$

Non-trivial Solution Condition: enables: Analysis of system stability in control theory
enables: Eigenvalue problems in structural vibrations

difficulty_factors: Common mistake: forgetting to set determinant to zero

textbook_references.author: Erwin Kreyszig
textbook_references.chapter_title: Linear Algebra: Matrices, Vectors, Determinants. Linear Systems
textbook_references.section: Homogeneous Linear Systems. Existence of Non-trivial Solutions
textbook_references.text_snippet: Non-trivial solutions exist if and only if the number of free variables in the system is greater than zero. This occurs when the rank (r) of the coefficient matrix A is strictly less than the number of unknowns (n).

textbook_references.author: B.S. Grewal
textbook_references.section: Conditions for Non-trivial Solutions of Homogeneous Equations
textbook_references.text_snippet: A homogeneous system A * X = 0 has non-trivial solutions if and only if the number of unknowns (n) is greater than the rank of the matrix A (rank(A) < n).

video_references.topic_covered: Row-reduced Echelon Matrices, Conditions for Non-trivial Solutions of Homogeneous Systems

video_references.professor: Prof. Sunita Gakkhar, Prof. H.G. Sharma, and Prof. Tanuja Srivastava
video_references.topic_covered: Homogeneous Systems and Solutions, Trivial and Non-trivial Solutions

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Matrix Formation → Determinant Calculation → Set to Zero → Solve for α
key_insights: For a square homogeneous system, non-trivial solutions exist iff the determinant of the coefficient matrix is zero.
The determinant condition is equivalent to the matrix being singular (rank < number of unknowns).

formulas_principles.name: Condition for Non-trivial Solution
formulas_principles.conditions: For a square homogeneous system (number of equations equals unknowns)

formulas_principles.formula: $\\text{det}(\\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\\\ d & e & f \\\\ g & h & i \\end{bmatrix}) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)$
formulas_principles.name: 3x3 Determinant Expansion
formulas_principles.conditions: Standard cofactor expansion along first row

industry_examples: Stability analysis in control systems: finding equilibrium points where small perturbations lead to non-zero responses.
Structural mechanics: solving for natural frequencies (eigenvalues) where the system admits non-trivial mode shapes.
specific_systems: Aircraft flutter analysis: homogeneous equations arise from stability derivatives.
Rocket guidance systems: linearized equations of motion about a trim condition.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Determining parameter values (like α) where a system loses uniqueness, indicating bifurcations, instabilities, or resonant conditions critical in aerospace design.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting that the trivial solution (x=y=z=0) always exists and incorrectly setting the determinant to non-zero.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusing homogeneous with non-homogeneous systems where determinant non-zero implies unique solution.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: For \\mathbf{A}\\mathbf{x} = 0, non-trivial solutions exist only if det(\\mathbf{A}) = 0. The trivial solution is always present.
common_mistakes.consequence: Will solve det(\\mathbf{A}) ≠ 0 and get incorrect α.

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrectly expanding the 3x3 determinant (sign errors or arithmetic mistakes).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing or misremembering the expansion formula, especially the signs for the cofactors.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Use systematic method (e.g., Sarrus' rule or careful cofactor expansion). Double-check arithmetic. Write intermediate steps.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrect determinant expression leads to wrong α.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming non-trivial solutions exist only when number of unknowns > number of equations (n > m). While sufficient, it's not necessary for square systems.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Overgeneralizing the theorem from retrieved knowledge (Chunk 1) without considering the square case.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: For square systems, the precise condition is det(\\mathbf{A}) = 0 (or rank < n). The condition n > m is a special case.
common_mistakes.consequence: Might think any α works because m=n=3, but actually need to check singularity.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: HOM-ZERO: Homogeneous, Zero determinant → Other (non-trivial) solutions exist.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Condition for non-trivial solutions in a square homogeneous system

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: SARRUS for 3x3: Write first two columns again to the right, sum products of diagonals (down-right positive, up-right negative).

flashcards.front: What is a non-trivial solution to a homogeneous system \\mathbf{A}\\mathbf{x} = 0?
flashcards.back: A solution vector \\mathbf{x} where at least one component is non-zero (\\mathbf{x} \\neq 0).

flashcards.front: State the necessary and sufficient condition for a square homogeneous system to have non-trivial solutions.
flashcards.back: The coefficient matrix \\mathbf{A} must be singular, i.e., det(\\mathbf{A}) = 0 (or equivalently, rank(\\mathbf{A}) < number of unknowns).

flashcards.front: Expand the determinant of a 3x3 matrix \\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\\\ d & e & f \\\\ g & h & i \\end{bmatrix} along the first row.
Why is it incorrect to assume det(\\mathbf{A}) \\neq 0 for a homogeneous system to have solutions?
flashcards.back: The trivial solution (\\mathbf{x}=0) always exists. Non-trivial solutions require det(\\mathbf{A}) = 0. A non-zero determinant implies only the trivial solution.

real_world_context.industry_example: Analyzing the longitudinal stability of an aircraft: the homogeneous linearized equations of motion yield a characteristic equation. Setting its determinant to zero finds eigenvalues, indicating stability margins.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Identifying parameter values where non-trivial solutions exist reveals critical flight conditions like divergence or flutter, essential for safe design.

real_world_context.industry_example: Determining natural frequencies of an aircraft wing: the homogeneous matrix equation ( [K] - \\omega^2 [M] ) {\\phi} = 0 has non-trivial mode shapes {\\phi} when the determinant of ( [K] - \\omega^2 [M] ) is zero.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Avoiding resonance requires knowing these frequencies, which are found by solving a parameter-dependent homogeneous system.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Quick 2-minute check: set up 3x3 determinant, compute, set to zero, solve. If arithmetic is done carefully, it's an easy mark.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, compute the determinant for a simple guess like α=0 or α=1 and see if it's zero; or note that the answer is likely a small integer.
exam_strategy.time_management: Spend no more than 3 minutes. If determinant expansion is messy, re-check signs and arithmetic.

search_keywords: homogeneous linear system non-trivial solution condition
linear algebra GATE previous year questions

alternative_methods.name: Row Reduction (Gaussian Elimination)
alternative_methods.description: Convert the coefficient matrix to Row Echelon Form (REF) or Reduced Row Echelon Form (RREF). The system has non-trivial solutions if the rank (number of non-zero rows) is less than the number of variables. This involves performing row operations on the augmented matrix [A|0] and finding conditions on α for a row of zeros or a free variable.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: More systematic, works for non-square systems. Cons: More steps, prone to arithmetic errors, requires careful handling of parameter α.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When the matrix is not square or when determinant calculation is cumbersome (e.g., larger matrices).

alternative_methods.name: Rank-Nullity Theorem Approach
alternative_methods.description: Use rank-nullity theorem: nullity(A) = n - rank(A). Non-trivial solutions exist if nullity(A) > 0, i.e., rank(A) < n. Compute rank(A) as a function of α (e.g., by finding minors) and set rank(A) < 3.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Connects to fundamental linear algebra concepts. Cons: Finding rank symbolically can be tricky for parameter-dependent matrices.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When you want to connect to theoretical concepts or when determinant is zero due to other reasons (like matrix not full rank).

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Linearized equations of motion lead to homogeneous systems for stability analysis (e.g., solving for eigenvalues).
connections_to_other_subjects.Structural Analysis: Finite element method yields homogeneous systems for natural frequencies and buckling loads.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: State-space representation: system modes are found from homogeneous state equations.

deeper_dive_topics: Eigenvalue problems: Homogeneous systems (A - λI)x = 0 are central to finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
Null space (kernel) of a matrix: The set of all non-trivial solutions forms a vector space.
Singular Value Decomposition (SVD): Relates to rank and non-trivial solutions in least squares problems.
Bifurcation theory: Parameters like α causing determinant zero indicate bifurcation points in dynamical systems.

syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Well-aligned with core linear algebra concepts tested in GATE AE.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided excellent, highly relevant knowledge on homogeneous systems, non-trivial solutions, and conditions for their existence (determinant zero, rank < n). All chunks reinforced the concept needed to solve the problem. The retrieved video notes and textbook references directly support the solution method and conceptual understanding.

future_questions_potential: Vary the number of equations/unknowns: Ask for condition on parameters for a 4x3 homogeneous system to have non-trivial solutions.
Combine with inhomogeneous systems: Given a system with a parameter, find values for which it has infinite solutions (both homogeneous and non-homogeneous parts).
Geometric interpretation: For a 2x2 homogeneous system, find parameter such that the lines are coincident (infinite solutions).
Application-based: In a spring-mass system, find mass value for which natural frequency is zero (non-trivial static deflection).

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text:
The system of equations
x - 2y + αz = 0
2x + y - 4z = 0
x - y + z = 0
has a non-trivial solution for α = ______. (Answer in integer)
